Summary I am an IT manager & entrepreneur based in Krakow, Poland. I combine excellent academic track record, strong hands-on technological background (machine learning/backend development in Google and a PhD course in Computer Science) with experience leading agile teams and driving quality products to their market delivery. 
 
I solve problems for living & for fun. I take a pragmatic approach to engineering: prototyping, experimenting, A|B testing & reiterating are central to my nature. I am pro-active and make my decisions in a data-driven way, putting users first. 
 
In the past, I have founded a VC-backed international startup, voluntarily run extracurricular courses for talented high-school students & recorded an album with a rock band. Experience Software Engineer III Google October 2014  – Present (11 months) Kraków Area, Poland I am a part of a team that builds the Customer Acquisition Platform - a Big Data-powered internal CRM/lead generation software for Google's 20000-people strong sales & marketing organization worldwide. We use heuristic filters and machine-learning models trained on Google's database of ~1 billion websites to find prospects promising in terms of potential ad spend, conversion propensity, seasonal activity & other factors. 
 
Personally, I have contributed the core infrastructure component that automates scoring and training with machine learning models, which runs up to 50 map/reduce multi-terabyte data pipelines a day. The infrastructure is used by a team of 20 engineers/researchers daily. Myself, I used it to generate, evaluate & launch: 
* a "stacked" advertiser propensity machine-learning model for American market - which increased acceptance rate for our lead generation efforts by sales reps from 12% to 32%. 
* a pre-sales acceptance machine-learning model for German market - our team's most selective model to date, which enabled to narrow down the prospect universe by 46% while dropping only 2% high spenders when applied to the past data 
* a set of seasonality filters for top DACH region verticals Chief Executive Officer MailGrupowy.pl sp. z o.o. September 2013  –  January 2015  (1 year 5 months) Kraków Area, Poland Served as a CEO of a VC-backed start-up with German capital in the social learning industry. I have driven growth in the Polish market (mailgrupowy.pl, up to 26% market share, >280% y/y user rate) and expansion to 2 foreign markets (India: mail4group.com, Turkey: mail-grubu.com). Managing product vision, recruitment efforts (team of up to 15 people), building corporate culture & strategy. 
 
For my earlier contributions to bringing this company to life, see a separate listing below. Project Manager AGH University of Science and Technology July 2012  –  December 2014  (2 years 6 months) Kraków Area, Poland Coordinated efforts of a team of researchers hired in the Polish National Science Center grant. 
The team has delivered 4 promising proof-of-concept products, published ~11 scientific papers (4 of which were published in the journals listed by the prestigious Journal Citation Reports), presented 8 papers on international conferences from the Web of Science list, and submitted a comprehensive report - all on time & in budget. Project Manager Pixellate February 2013  –  October 2013  (9 months) Kraków Area, Poland I have led an agile team of ~8 Python/Django/jQuery engineers in a local software house. We have delivered: 
* a geo-social networking website for our British client (http://meetupon.com) 
* an online taxi booking platform for our German client (http://talixo.com); the startup behind this website raised €X million in funding, using our product for their pitch (http://techcrunch.com/2014/04/23/talixo-funding/); later they acquired our software house, to continue development with our engineers in-house. Product Manager MailGrupowy.pl February 2011  –  September 2013  (2 years 8 months) Kraków Area, Poland MailGrupowy.pl is a social learning startup with a goal to revolutionize how student groups interact when learning. 
 
As a Product Manager / founder, I have: 
* created product vision, gathered 3 co-founders, launched a minimal viable product in 7 months 
* maintained feature backlog, gathered user feedback, ensured user experience & usability 
* measured impact of previous decisions (A|B testing, advanced Google Analytics) 
* performed growth hacking (SEO/SEM, guerrilla marketing, Facebook ads & social API) 
 
The product attracted ~100000 users on Polish market on virtually no budget within 2 years from launch. After that, we raised financing from the Polish industry leader in social learning. I became the CEO of the joint venture formed as a result (http://goaleurope.com/2013/09/19/polish-brainly-invests-240k-euro-in-mailgrupowy-pl/). 
 
For my efforts at turning this successful product into a profitable company, see the listing above. Software Engineer - Intern NVIDIA October 2012  –  February 2013  (5 months) Durham, North Carolina, USA Mobile diagnostics team 
 
Took ownership of memory tests area for Tegra (mobile System on a Chip used e.g. in Galaxy Tab 10). Supported internal & external customers with regards to tests' development and usage. Played a role on the critical path of the new NVIDIA mobile chip bring-up. Software Engineer - Intern Google July 2012  –  October 2012  (4 months) Zurich, Switzerland Google Calendar team 
 
* Took ownership of Google Calendar Mobile front end (JavaScript + Google Closure / Java / HTML5) 
* Seamlessly migrated it from a deprecated Gdata API to a new JSON-based API System Software Engineer - Intern NVIDIA July 2011  –  September 2011  (3 months) Santa Clara, California, USA Mobile diagnostics team 
 
* Proposed and build support for the idea for major refactoring of the legacy JavaScript / C++ interface used in the diagnostic framework by ~20 engineers. Led development with 2 other interns, tested and launched it (a voluntary side project) 
* Diagnosed and fixed multiple issues concerning the camera module and the CPUs of NVIDIA's Tegra T30 chip for mobile devices (the actual assigned project) (C++ / JavaScript) 
* Coordinated externalization of team's best practices, customer instructions and new hire tips on a corporate wiki webpage (a voluntary side project) System Software Engineer - Intern NVIDIA July 2010  –  September 2010  (3 months) Santa Clara, California, USA Mobile diagnostics team 
 
* Developed an alternative, object-oriented, test-friendly driver for the Image Signal Processor camera hardware module of NVIDIA's mobile Tegra AP20 chip (C++) 
* Created a bench of test cases - based on both 'golden image' approach (comparison with results computed on another instance of the chip, which is assumed to work well) and algorithmic approach (based on software reconstruction of the algorithm performed by the hardware) (C++ / JavaScript) Financial Software Developer - Intern Bloomberg June 2010  –  August 2010  (3 months) London, United Kingdom Data Services Support team

Experience Mobile App Search & Indexing - Engineering Manager, Tech Lead, Staff Software Engineer Google July 2014  – Present (1 year 2 months) Mountain View, CA Manage a team to index, understand, and serve the content in mobile apps. Social Graph Service - Staff Software Engineer, Tech Lead Google January 2012  –  July 2014  (2 years 7 months) Mountain View, CA - The Social Graph Service provides a unified data model and API over all social graph data at Google. It is the central place for reading/writing membership data of G+ Circles, Hangout, G+ Communities, G+ Events and Google Voice, and reading user profiles. The service is a core component of several Google services including Google Plus, Hangout, and Google Voice. 
- As the Tech Lead of the Social Graph Core team, led a team of 5 engineers to develop the main system in Java on top of Spanner storage and ST index, and managed collaboration with clients to support new products and use cases. 
- Drove the design and implementation of the system for scalability (10+B user membership edges and 1M queries/second across 15 data centers), performance (under 12ms mean latency), consistency and client integration (70+ clients). 
- Personally wrote most of the system's backend serving layer and indexing solution. 
- Drove the migration of the system's storage from Megastore to Spanner, in the process significantly increasing the system's scalability (from 100 writes/seconds to 30+K writes/second) and consistency (full serializability). Completed the migration with zero system down-time or change to clients. 
- Led the launch of Hangout, G+ Communities and G+ Vanity URLs on Social Graph Service. Designed and implemented end-to-end indexing solution on top of ST index to support fast group chat lookup and various sorted views in Hangout client. Optimized the system's serving logic to reduce machine usage by 3X. Google Play Music - Senior Software Engineer, Tech Lead, Architect Google November 2007  –  January 2012  (4 years 3 months) Mountain View, CA - The Metadata Management Service handles the storage, relationship management, retrieval, and matching of 30+M tracks and the associated metadata. It aggregates the artist, album and track metadata from hundreds of music labels, and manages the complex relationship in the data. It facilitates the matching of all ingested music content, and powers core functionalities such as music search, Scan-and-Match of user uploaded content, and recommendations. 
- Architected the system end-to-end. Personally wrote the first version of the system in C++ on top of Bigtable storage. 
- Engineered end-to-end metadata matching system that matches raw content from music labels and user uploads to existing music store records. The system supports the re-ingestion and matching of the entire music corpus in under a day, and instant update of newly ingested content in under 2 hours. 
 
- The Music Store Service powers the search and browsing experience in the Google Play music store, and is the central business server for music search results, purchase fulfillment, manually curated content, and customer reviews. It serves 20+K queries/second, 100+K orders and $300+K revenue per day. 
- Built the service in Java on top of ST index (search results), Zipit (reviews), and Checkout (orders). 
 
- Led a team of 6 to develop the frontend service in Java and client music player in JavaScript. Drove product features and designs with product managers and UI designers. Web Suggest - Software Engineer III, Tech Lead Google September 2006  –  November 2007  (1 year 3 months) Mountain View, CA - Web Suggest is the feature that completes your query as you type in the search box. It started out as an experimental feature developed by 20% contributors. I was the first full-time engineer on the project. 
- As the Tech Lead of a 5-engineer team, productionized the system and graduated the product from experimental status. Drove the launch of the product in Asian markets (China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong). Achieved 25% feature adoption, increased average query length by 2%, and saved adopted users 48% keystrokes. 
- Using a Bayesian bigram model trained with query data in web logs, built the Chinese pinyin suggest feature that enabled Chinese users to input pinyin and get a list of matched Chinese character query completions. This greatly improved the search experience of Chinese users, allowing them to perform searches even when they do not have IME installed. Web Search - Software Engineer II Google October 2005  –  September 2006  (1 year) Mountain View, CA - Built using Python the Continuous Quality Evaluation Pipeline for CJK language segmenter to generate quality evaluation runs for quality experiments, and aggregate evaluation results. This enabled the evaluation, optimization, and ultimately the launch of Google's in-house CJK language segmenter that replaced the buggy and black-box third-party segmentation software we were using. 
- Implemented various web search frontend features including search query language encoding detection, and safesearch and results ranking twiddling for CJK queries. Summary I'm a generalist hacker with an eerie knack for absorbing new skills. I've successfully worked in a variety of fields. I like to work with people who can do things I can't (yet) so that I can learn from them. 
 
I strongly prefer collaborative, constructive, positive team environments with a diversity of background, skillset, and gender. I have a low tolerance for zero-sum games or office politics. Let's help each other get something done. Experience Founder, Flight Systems Tech Lead, Project Loon (Staff Sw.Eng.) Google August 2011  – Present (4 years 1 month) Mountain View, CA I co-founded Project Loon in 2011 with Josh Weaver and Rich DeVaul. There were too few of us to specialize, so I worked on software, circuits, mechanicals, tracking systems, parachute selection... you name it. 
 
Since then I have helped guide the project's growth and productization, hiring lots of excitingly brilliant people. My main focus since 2012 has been the avionics firmware and associated infrastructure (toolchains, libraries, build environment), though I've also helped with flight termination system design, polymer stress analysis, and the FPGAs that drive our [redacted]. 
 
I've learned a lot about embedded software design for a large team, hardware-in-the-loop test, managing an integrated SW/HW/manufacturing effort, and the exciting lives of capacitors at -60C and low pressure. 
 
I was promoted to Staff Software Engineer during this time. UX Prototyper, Project Glass (Senior Sw.Eng.) Google March 2011  –  August 2011  (6 months) Mountain View, CA During the early stages of Glass, I was part of a UX prototyping team under Thad Starner. Ed Keyes and I built the first hardware that resembled its present form and was comfortable enough for all-day wear (Ed was mostly hardware, I was mostly software). At the time I joined, Glass prototypes ranged from backpack- to helmet-sized and couldn't show notifications from your phone; the final product looks an awful lot like our protoype, albeit with a camera (something I argued strongly against). 
 
From my colleagues on Glass I learned a lot about digital electronics design, display technology, Bluetooth, Android, miniaturization, speaking truth to power, and how to solder tricky little QFNs whose package must remain optically clear but will fog if overheated. Senior Software Engineer, Native Client Google May 2009  –  March 2011  (1 year 11 months) Mountain View, CA Native Client is an entirely new approach to software security that lets untrusted (even malicious) code run harmlessly on existing operating systems. It has been described by Google software engineers as "crazy crashed-flying-saucer technology." For organizational reasons it has been primarily used to run games in web browsers. So it goes. 
 
The NaCl folks and I had talked earlier, but their original focus on x86-32 didn't interest me; they eventually poached me once an ARM porting effort started. I helped with the initial port, writing the instruction set validator and working on the LLVM-based compiler and runtime. We eventually beat the performance of the x86 version despite not having any hardware support -- we were within 2% of unsandboxed code on SPEC. 
 
I helped design the mechanisms for dynamically inserting and removing code (critical for shared libraries) and for generating and modifying code on the fly (critical for languages like Java or JavaScript). 
 
From these crazy-smart folks I learned basically everything I know about compiler internals, optimizations, self-certifying and proof-carrying code, the ARM family microarchitectures, and the importance of a small trusted code base. 
 
I left NaCl only because Google[x] happened. Software Engineer III, Ads Review Google January 2006  –  May 2009  (3 years 5 months) Mountain View, CA I worked in the AdWords unit for 3.5 years writing large distributed Java systems that filtered out bad ads. My team dramatically improved the automation rate -- total costs saved and revenue from new markets we enabled added up to many hundreds of millions of dollars. From this team I learned a lot about text processing, machine learning, distributed systems, and user experience design -- not to mention software engineering practices in a codebase supported by a very large team (~100 engineers). 
 
I was promoted from Sw.Eng. II to III to Senior during this time. Programmer/Analyst II Choice Hotels International March 2004  –  December 2005  (1 year 10 months) Phoenix, AZ Worked on OLTP/OLAP systems that drive the Choice Privileges loyalty program; some web work; minimal reservation system work. 
 
I was responsible for the integration with Bank of America, on Choice's side, for the co-branded Choice Privileges VISA card. 
 
Choice was the first "big company" environment I worked in, and I learned a lot about what to do (and what not to do) on large teams. This was my first real exposure to what would later be called SOA, and my first time working with a rigorous team who placed value on things like design specifications, unit tests, agility, and hot failover. 
 
Google successfully poached me from this job. Senior Developer Global Internet Solutions, Inc. March 2003  –  December 2003  (10 months) Tempe, AZ Developed and supported e-commerce sites for several well-known Phoenix companies. Managed a team of two programmers. Founding Partner, Senior Developer Extrasensory Applications, Inc. March 2002  –  March 2003  (1 year 1 month) Phoenix, AZ Startup to take on Ticketmaster through the new (at the time) idea of "mobile paperless ticketing." A few years too early in hindsight. 
 
I learned a lot about business operations, accounting, and in particular the importance of business development and networking to the success of even upstart, disruptive operations. Senior Developer, Systems Administrator AZSites LLC August 2001  –  March 2002  (8 months) Tempe, AZ Full-stack e-commerce development using PHP, FreeBSD, Apache, MySQL. Managed a team of programmers and graphics designers on coordinated projects. 
 
Left (with my dev team) when the paychecks stopped. Interface Developer Network Safety Group August 1999  –  November 2000  (1 year 4 months) Scottsdale, AZ Returned to the reformed Network Safety Group and resumed role developing firewall/network configuration software, this time in Java/Swing. Developed high-performance Java cryptography code for interpreted (1.1) JVMs, and subsequently reoptimized for HotSpot (1.2+). Designed cryptographic communication and key distribution protocols for resistance to replay and man-in-the-middle attacks. Programmer Cobalt Creative, Inc. May 1999  –  August 1999  (4 months) Scottsdale, AZ Developed client applications in DHTML, ASP, JavaScript, Visual J++, VBScript, Visual Basic, and Flash. Supported graphics designers, including some Photoshop/Fireworks work. 
 
This was a summer job during college. Senior Windows Programmer Network Safety Corporation April 1993  –  November 1998  (5 years 8 months) Cave Creek, AZ Developed and supported WebElite, one of the first commercially-available HTML editors, initially on Win16 and later on Win32 and NT. 
 
Developed Windows-based firewall and network configuration software for the NetNAT line of firewalls, on WinNT 3.51/4.0 and Win95. My employment here was interrupted by my graduation from high school. Founder, Flight Systems Tech Lead, Project Loon (Staff Sw.Eng.) I was promoted to Staff Software Engineer during this time. UX Prototyper, Project Glass (Senior Sw.Eng.) Google March 2011  –  August 2011  (6 months) Mountain View, CA During the early stages of Glass, I was part of a UX prototyping team under Thad Starner. Ed Keyes and I built the first hardware that resembled its present form and was comfortable enough for all-day wear (Ed was mostly hardware, I was mostly software). At the time I joined, Glass prototypes ranged from backpack- to helmet-sized and couldn't show notifications from your phone; the final product looks an awful lot like our protoype, albeit with a camera (something I argued strongly against). 
 
From my colleagues on Glass I learned a lot about digital electronics design, display technology, Bluetooth, Android, miniaturization, speaking truth to power, and how to solder tricky little QFNs whose package must remain optically clear but will fog if overheated. Senior Software Engineer, Native Client Google May 2009  –  March 2011  (1 year 11 months) Mountain View, CA Native Client is an entirely new approach to software security that lets untrusted (even malicious) code run harmlessly on existing operating systems. It has been described by Google software engineers as "crazy crashed-flying-saucer technology." For organizational reasons it has been primarily used to run games in web browsers. So it goes. 
 
The NaCl folks and I had talked earlier, but their original focus on x86-32 didn't interest me; they eventually poached me once an ARM porting effort started. I helped with the initial port, writing the instruction set validator and working on the LLVM-based compiler and runtime. We eventually beat the performance of the x86 version despite not having any hardware support -- we were within 2% of unsandboxed code on SPEC. 
 
I helped design the mechanisms for dynamically inserting and removing code (critical for shared libraries) and for generating and modifying code on the fly (critical for languages like Java or JavaScript). 
 
From these crazy-smart folks I learned basically everything I know about compiler internals, optimizations, self-certifying and proof-carrying code, the ARM family microarchitectures, and the importance of a small trusted code base. 
 
I left NaCl only because Google[x] happened. Computer vision, simulation and modelling Experience Software Engineer III Google December 2013  – Present (1 year 9 months) Sydney Area, Australia I write monitoring, measurement and management software for Google's production network. 
 
I specialise in trying to answer the most difficult questions - how do our processes, workflows and operational procedures impact the availability, cost and scalability of one of the largest networks in the world? Do managers who adopt new practices create productivity gains for their teams? Which hardware vendors provide the most reliable equipment, and how does this weigh against their costing? Can we define a TCO for a Juniper router vs a Brocade router that includes hardware cost, amortised median cost of network outages based on failure rates, employee-hour costings for maintenance and upgrade tasks? 
 
Instrumenting, measuring, analysing and producing concrete suggestions is an interesting and complex task; and I am currently focused on providing Google with the best metrics while learning all I can from my skilled peers.
